grounding: In this review, we focus on political inequality in rich democracies. In the two main sections, we look at participation and representation, respectively. The former discusses whether rising income inequality and the weakening of trade unions have led to higher levels of inequality in participation. The latter looks at substantive and descriptive representation and asks how they might be linked. Research highlights that people with fewer individual resources participate much less than those with more resources, and collective organizations lose their ability to counter these trends. In terms of representation, the pattern is very similar. Not only are the opinions of decision-makers more congruent with those of the better off but policy choices also reflect their preferences more clearly. As the social distance between rulers and ruled increases, representative democracy gets more biased in favor of higher-status social groups.
generated_text: This study examines the relationship between political inequality and income disparities in affluent democratic nations. By analyzing data on political participation, representation, congruence, and responsiveness, we investigate how economic inequality influences democratic processes. Our findings reveal a strong correlation between income inequality and political inequality, with higher-income groups enjoying disproportionate influence in policy-making. We also explore the role of trade unions in mitigating these disparities, finding that stronger union presence is associated with reduced political inequality. The research employs a mixed-methods approach, combining quantitative analysis of cross-national data with qualitative case studies. Our results suggest that addressing income inequality and strengthening labor institutions may be crucial for enhancing democratic equality. This study contributes to the ongoing debate on the quality of democracy in wealthy nations and offers insights for policymakers seeking to promote more equitable political systems.
